page.title: 10The River Stour
page.content: In the past London needed wheat and barley for bread and beer and bricks for building.Villages and towns along the Stour could provide them.Roadswere bad So a company was formed to widen and deepen the river from Sudbury to Maningtree allowing barges to carry these goods to London and coal to be brought back.Locks and weirs were built and the barges were pulled by horses. Mills,warehouses and wharves were also built and the company charged tolls to use the river.The building of the Gt. Eastern Railway caused the company to close in 1914 and destroy their barges. The river today is only used for leisure (fishing and boat trips) but Cornard Lock is to be rebuilt,Cornard Mill remains as do the wharf and warehouse at Sudbury.The Colchester/ Sudbury Railway built in 1849 caused the closure of the Stour Navigation.
